author: Matt Holden
title: Post Melbourne Festival: Where to slake your thirst
text:
Boilermaker House on Lonsdale Street, Melbourne. Photo: Paul Jeffers 
SPONSORED 
Devotion to detail has brought Rita Ambroz and Joe Jones recognition. Their bar, Romeo Lane, won  The Age Good Food Guide  2016 Bar of the Year just 12 months after opening. 
"It's all in the details, from the rows of cut-glass decanters that glitter against every dark wooden panel to the most perfectly crafted Trinidad sour you're likely to find in the city," said the  Good Food Guide judges.
Michael Madrusan at the Everleigh, Fitzroy. Photo: Simon Schluter 
 "The beers and wines are just as well chosen – even the bar nuts are salted almonds, served in a little glass box and wreathed in smoke. Good times and Billie Holiday guaranteed – oh, and it's open both early (3pm) and late, for your drinking pleasure."
Advertisement Devotion to detail, and to serving a diversity of drinks in spaces both small and curated or large and loud, is what helps make Melbourne's bar scene so enticing. 
At Boilermaker House on Lonsdale Street, courtesy of the same team behind Eau de Vie bar (EDV), easy-drinking beers and whiskies slake thirsts, while cheeses and charcuterie satisfy the peckish.
In the charmed hands of bartenders, beer paired with a nip of thoughtfully considered whisky can become a thing of wonder, to be admired and enjoyed. When your beer or brew of choice is served until 3am, it's more charming still.
Michael Madrusan, the man behind The Everleigh in Fitzroy, is devoted to creating exceptional drinks and exceptional spaces in which to enjoy them; a devotion that began with the most basic ingredient of all – ice.
Early in his bar-tending career, Madrusan spent three months of a New York City winter cutting ice by hand to get his foot in the door at Milk & Honey, the legendary Manhattan bar that put together a superb drinks selection for a thirsty, sophisticated crowd. 
"I used to go in during the off-hours and cut ice with a hammer and an icepick," he says. "It took me three months before I got my first shift." That first shift was as a host, not a bartender: "It was six months between my first hosting gig and my first bar shift."
"When I came in it was an incredibly romantic time to be a bartender. We had this reputation, we were part of something really big. Seeing what Milk and Honey has inspired around the world – it's pretty nuts."
The Everleigh is regularly named in lists of the world's best bars and Madrusan is likewise sought out for his mixology expertise. 
Tash Conte is one of the Melbourne bar scene's originals – she opened Black Pearl Bar in Fitzroy in 2001. BPB is a regular in the world's 50 best bar lists and Conte says that being a family business is one of the keys to their longevity and success.
The Pearl's upstairs Attic bar has table service, select beers and wines are available and staff make the sodas and syrups in-house from scratch.
"It's about selling great drinks, creating a great ambience and offering great hospitality," Conte says.

Post Melbourne festival bars 

Boilermaker House 
Rotating tap beers, diverse easy-drinking brews, whiskies galore and excellent offerings from the kitchen, all downed in a bar that seems fashionably tatty, in a good way.
209 Lonsdale Street, 0424 270 082. Mon-Wed 5pm-3am, Thu-Sun noon-3am. 
Romeo Lane 
This little gem, hidden near Pellegrini's, serves drinks in (mostly) vintage glassware, alongside freshly shucked oysters. A class act.
1a Crossley Street, Melbourne, 03 9639 8095,  romeolane.com.au 
Eau de Vive 
Clever drinks assembled with charm and flair by a crack team in a flatteringly lit, louche, members-club style bar.
1 Malthouse Lane, Melbourne, 0412 825 441,  eaudevie.com.au/melbourne 

The Everleigh 
Table service, meticulous attention to drinks, glassware, recipes, service and even perfect ice: it's easy to see why many consider The Everleigh among the best in the world.
Level 1, 150-156 Gertrude Street, Fitzroy, 03 9416 2229  theeverleigh.com 

Forester's Hall 
With 50 taps pouring beers, surely every taste is catered for at this Collingwood favourite, its 4 am licence surely indicating a devotion to the nocturnal desires of patrons? 
64 Smith Street, Collingwood, 03 8415 1104.
